channel.title: CPU problem
channel.description:
I'm having problems with my CPU, it keeps dropping to 0% usage and all my applications freeze. It seems to be spiking quiet a lot. It usually runs at around 20% and maybe 10% idle.
Does anybody know what might be the problem for it dropping to 0% randomly?
Edit: This happens when I try run a program as administrator, the security box will appear saying do I want to run this blah blah, when I press yes, the screen will stay dim and I cannot do anything (because CPU dropped to 0%). I have to press ctrl+alt+del to restore it all, and the application will not load. This can be for anything that requires admin privileges such as installing a program.
I'm using Windows 7.

item.title: CPU problem
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“Jmood, post:8, topic:543811”][quote author=SilentCJ link=topic=662691.msg4429186#msg4429186 date=1402390946]
Try disable UAC, probably avoiding the problem but it would certainly bypass the stupid ‘Allow access’ popups (one of the first things I do with a new Windows installation). If that requires admin privilege to disable it, then try it through safe mode.

After you’ve disabled it you should be able to do all the above.
[/quote]

I guess its a good thing you don’t use Linux.[/quote]
Uhh, I use FreeBSD and Mac OS X daily… why?

Read full topic

item.title: CPU problem
item.dc:creator: @doom_j doom_j
item.description:
@doom_j wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:6, topic:543811”]Try disable UAC, probably avoiding the problem but it would certainly bypass the stupid ‘Allow access’ popups (one of the first things I do with a new Windows installation). If that requires admin privilege to disable it, then try it through safe mode.

After you’ve disabled it you should be able to do all the above.[/quote]

I guess its a good thing you don’t use Linux.

Read full topic

item.title: CPU problem
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

I had many bad sectors in my HDD and corrupt windows files (guess that’s what happens after 5 years from rebooting from power button). It’s working for now.

Thanks for the help everybody.

Read full topic

item.title: CPU problem
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Try disable UAC, probably avoiding the problem but it would certainly bypass the stupid ‘Allow access’ popups (one of the first things I do with a new Windows installation). If that requires admin privilege to disable it, then try it through safe mode.

After you’ve disabled it you should be able to do all the above.

Read full topic

item.title: CPU problem
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“Ruby, post:4, topic:543811”][quote author=Ashi link=topic=662691.msg4429071#msg4429071 date=1402337741]

I’m having problems with my CPU, it keeps dropping to 0% usage and all my applications freeze. It seems to be spiking quiet a lot. It usually runs at around 20% and maybe 10% idle.

Does anybody know what might be the problem for it dropping to 0% randomly?

What kind of applications are you running while it freezes?

Updated thread, it’s with anything that needs admin rights.
[/quote]
This article looks pretty promising. All I’d have said to do is to run a virus scan, if there’s nothing showing up restore win 7.[/quote]
Well nothing shows up from a virus scan. I have firewall and other security usually off. I cannot start my anti virus anymore because I need admin rights (fail). I already have my settings for clean boot.

I couldn’t follow any of the steps in the article because even the System File Checker tool you need admin rights lol

Thanks for trying though.

Edit: This is a windows problem because Linux works perfectly fine. Thankfully it’s not a hardware problem.

Edit: I think it’s a problem with my HDD (windows partition) strangely a hell of a lot of it is corrupt and bad!

Read full topic

Does anybody know what might be the problem for it dropping to 0% randomly?

What kind of applications are you running while it freezes?
[/quote]
Updated thread, it’s with anything that needs admin rights.[/quote]
This article looks pretty promising. All I’d have said to do is to run a virus scan, if there’s nothing showing up restore win 7.

Read full topic
